1.brief: to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
a year (as a revolution of time)
the new moon; by implication, a month
properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first
the new moon; by implication, a month
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
near, with or among; often in general, to

2.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative
a dirge (as accompanied by beating the breasts or on instruments)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
Paroh, a general title of Egyptian kings
a king
Mitsrajim, i.e. Upper and Lower Egypt
to say (used with great latitude)
near, with or among; often in general, to
a village (as covered in by walls); also a young lion (perhaps as covered with a mane)
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
to compare; by implication, to resemble, liken, consider
thou and thee, or (plural) ye and you
a monster (as preternaturally formed), i.e. a sea-serpent (or other huge marine animal); also a jackal (or other hideous land animal)

a sea (as breaking in noisy surf) or large body of water; specifically (with the article), the Mediterranean Sea; sometimes a large river, or an artifical basin; locally, the west, or (rarely) the south
to gush forth (as water), generally to issue
a stream (including the sea; expectation the Nile, Euphrates, etc.); figuratively, prosperity
to roil water
water; figuratively, juice; by euphemism, urine, semen
a foot (as used in walking); by implication, a step; by euphemistically the pudenda
to trample, i.e. roil water
a stream (including the sea; expectation the Nile, Euphrates, etc.); figuratively, prosperity

3.brief: properly, like this, i.e. by implication, (of manner) thus (or so); also (of place) here (or hither); or (of time) now
the Lord (used as a proper name of God only)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative
physical (as shutting in) a net (either literally or figuratively); usually a doomed object; abstractly extermination

4.brief: properly, to pound, i.e. smite; by implication (as if beating out, and thus expanding) to disperse; also, to thrust off, down, out or upon (inclusively, reject, let alone, permit, remit, etc.)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
to pitch over or reel; hence (transitively) to cast down or out
to reside or permanently stay (literally or figuratively)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a bird (as covered with feathers, or rather as covering with wings), often collectively
the sky (as aloft; the dual perhaps alluding to the visible arch in which the clouds move, as well as to the higher ether where the celestial bodies revolve)
to sate, i.e. fill to satisfaction (literally or figuratively)
properly, a part of; hence (prepositionally), from or out of in many senses
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)

5.brief: to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
flesh (from its freshness); by extension, body, person; also (by euphemistically) the pudenda of aman
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
to fill or (intransitively) be full of, in a wide application (literally and figuratively)
a gorge (from its lofty sides; hence, narrow, but not a gully or winter-torrent)

6.brief: to quaff, i.e. (causatively) to irrigate or furnish apotion to
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)
near, with or among; often in general, to
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
properly, containing, i.e. a tube; also a bed or valley of astream; also a strong thing or a hero
to fill or (intransitively) be full of, in a wide application (literally and figuratively)
properly, a part of; hence (prepositionally), from or out of in many senses

to expire or (causatively) to extinguish (fire, light, anger)
the sky (as aloft; the dual perhaps alluding to the visible arch in which the clouds move, as well as to the higher ether where the celestial bodies revolve)
to be ashy, i.e. darkcolored; by implication, to mourn (in sackcloth or sordid garments)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
a star (as round or as shining); figuratively, a prince
the sun; by implication, the east; figuratively, a ray, i.e. (architectural) a notched battlement
a cloud (as covering the sky), i.e. the nimbus or thunder-cloud
properly, to plump, i.e. fill up hollows; by implication, to cover (for clothing or secrecy)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to be (causative, make) luminous (literally and metaphorically)
illumination or (concrete) luminary (in every sense, including lightning, happiness, etc.)

the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
the Lord (used as a proper name of God only)

the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
a fracture, figuratively, ruin; specifically, a solution (of a dream)
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
